artwork_title: 东北书 / A Book of Northeast China

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 「东北人的成年礼是一张南下的车票」——这句话击中了我。这本手工书不是在记录东北，而是在书写一种离开的仪式。每一页翻动，都像是火车窗外掠过的风景：水塔、南湖公园、童年照片……它们不再是地点，而是时间的锚点。艺术家用传统装帧包裹着现代的乡愁，这本身就是一种矛盾：我们用古老的方式保存那些正在消逝的东西。
turns.content_en: "A Northeasterner's coming-of-age ritual is a southbound train ticket"—this line struck me deeply. This handmade book is not documenting the Northeast, but writing a ritual of departure. Each page turned is like scenery flashing past a train window: water towers, Nanhu Park, childhood photos... They are no longer places, but anchors in time. The artist wraps modern nostalgia in traditional binding—this itself is a contradiction: we use ancient methods to preserve things that are disappearing.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 韩雪说得对，但我想从另一个维度切入：这本书最打动我的是它的五感结构。艺术家没有选择线性叙事，而是用记忆、听觉、嗅觉、味觉、触觉、视觉来组织内容。这是人类学式的分类法。想想看：《月儿明风儿静》的摇篮曲、丹东草莓的香气、锅包肉的酸甜、冰雪的触感——这些不是视觉档案能捕捉的。身体比眼睛记得更多。当我们说「想家」，我们想的不是画面，而是感觉。
turns.content_en: Han Xue is right, but I want to approach from another dimension: what moves me most about this book is its five-sense structure. The artist didn't choose linear narrative, but organized content through memory, hearing, smell, taste, touch, and vision. This is an anthropological classification. Think about it: the lullaby "The Moon is Bright, the Wind is Calm," the fragrance of Dandong strawberries, the sweet-and-sour of Guobaorou, the touch of ice and snow—these cannot be captured by visual archives. The body remembers more than the eyes. When we say "I miss home," we're not thinking of images, but of sensations.

turns.speaker: su_shi
turns.content: 二位所言，皆触及此书之妙。然余以为，此书最可贵者，在于其「不尽之意」。诗中有画，画中有诗——此书亦然。摄影与文字相融，却不相互解释，而是彼此留白。譬如「东北不仅是地理位置，也是一种心理状态」一语，便有味外之味。东坡尝谓「论画以形似，见与儿童邻」，此书不求形似，而求神韵——东北之神韵，非山川形胜，乃人心之所安也。
turns.content_en: What you both say touches the essence of this book. Yet I believe its most precious quality lies in its "unfinished meaning." Poetry in painting, painting in poetry—this book is the same. Photography and text merge, yet don't explain each other, but leave space for each other. For instance, "The Northeast is not just a geographical location, but also a psychological state"—this phrase has flavor beyond flavor. As I once said, "To judge painting by form alone is to see like a child." This book seeks not resemblance but spiritual resonance—the spirit of the Northeast lies not in mountains and rivers, but in where the heart finds peace.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 苏轼先生提到「心理状态」，这让我想起作品中那句「舒服、幸福、悠闲、质朴」。这几个词很日常，甚至有点「土」，但恰恰是这种不修饰的真诚让我动容。东北人的表达方式就是这样——不绕弯子，不讲究措辞。艺术家用手工书这种「慢」的媒介来承载这种「直」的情感，形成了一种有趣的张力。我们在快速流动的时代，用最传统的方式，记住最朴素的东西。
turns.content_en: Master Su Shi mentions "psychological state," which reminds me of that phrase in the work: "comfortable, happy, leisurely, simple." These words are everyday, even a bit "rustic," but it's precisely this unadorned sincerity that moves me. This is how Northeasterners express themselves—no beating around the bush, no fancy words. The artist uses the "slow" medium of handmade books to carry this "direct" emotion, creating an interesting tension. In an era of rapid movement, we use the most traditional methods to remember the most simple things.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 韩雪提到的「慢」让我想到这本书的物质性。传统中国书籍装帧——线装、宣纸、手工折叠——本身就是一种触觉体验。读者必须亲手翻页，感受纸张的厚度和温度。这和我们刷手机看东北vlog完全不同。艺术家故意选择了一种需要身体参与的媒介，这是对数字时代的一种抵抗，也是对「慢记忆」的坚持。冻梨需要慢慢化开才好吃，记忆也需要慢慢展开才有味道。
turns.content_en: Han Xue's mention of "slow" makes me think of this book's materiality. Traditional Chinese book binding—thread-bound, rice paper, hand-folded—is itself a tactile experience. Readers must turn pages by hand, feeling the thickness and temperature of paper. This is completely different from scrolling through Northeast vlogs on phones. The artist deliberately chose a medium requiring bodily participation—this is resistance to the digital age, and insistence on "slow memory." Frozen pears need to thaw slowly to taste good; memories also need to unfold slowly to have flavor.

turns.speaker: su_shi
turns.content: 李梅言及「慢」与「触觉」，余深以为然。昔余谪居黄州，常忆蜀中山水，然所忆者非形色，乃竹林风声、溪水凉意也。此书亦然：艺术家不求全面再现东北，而是撷取那些最能触动五感的碎片。碎片之间的留白，正是观者可以填入自己记忆之处。一本好书，不是让人读完就忘，而是让人读后能「续」——以自己的经验续写未尽之意。此书有此品格，可谓得艺术之真谛。
turns.content_en: Li Mei speaks of "slow" and "touch," and I deeply agree. When I was exiled to Huangzhou, I often recalled the mountains and waters of Sichuan, yet what I remembered was not shapes and colors, but the sound of wind in bamboo groves, the coolness of streams. This book is the same: the artist doesn't seek to fully recreate the Northeast, but gathers fragments that most touch the five senses. The blank spaces between fragments are where viewers can fill in their own memories. A good book doesn't make you forget after reading, but allows you to "continue"—to extend the unfinished meaning with your own experience. This book has this quality—it has grasped the true essence of art.

notes: 首次生成，使用家庭档案类角色组合

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 这组作品让我想起了1958年的「除四害」运动。麻雀被列为四害之一，全国动员捕杀，东北也不例外。一年后，害虫失去天敌，粮食大面积受损。这是一段被选择性遗忘的历史。艺术家选择麻雀作为主题，是在召唤一个幽灵——那个被政策错误抹杀的物种，以及与之一同消失的生态平衡和人的尊严。油画的厚重质感，恰好承载了这种历史的重量。
turns.content_en: This series reminds me of the "Four Pests Campaign" of 1958. Sparrows were listed as one of the four pests, mobilizing nationwide extermination—the Northeast was no exception. A year later, pests lost their natural predators, causing massive crop damage. This is a history selectively forgotten. The artist choosing sparrows as subject is summoning a ghost—that species erased by policy error, along with the ecological balance and human dignity that disappeared with it. The thick texture of oil painting aptly carries this weight of history.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 张伟教授的历史视角让我想到另一层含义：麻雀也是东北人的隐喻。我们这代人，像麻雀一样四散南飞，离开那片土地。但麻雀有归巢的本能，而我们呢？艺术家画了四只麻雀，或许正是四个季节、四个方向、四种命运。画布上的麻雀静默着，却像是在等待什么——等待春天，等待回家，等待被重新看见。这不仅是历史画，更是乡愁的肖像。
turns.content_en: Professor Zhang's historical perspective makes me think of another layer: sparrows are also a metaphor for Northeasterners. Our generation scattered south like sparrows, leaving that land. But sparrows have a homing instinct—what about us? The artist painted four sparrows, perhaps representing four seasons, four directions, four fates. The sparrows on canvas are silent, yet seem to be waiting for something—waiting for spring, waiting to go home, waiting to be seen again. This is not just historical painting, but a portrait of nostalgia.

turns.speaker: su_shi
turns.content: 二位从历史与情感入手，余则从画理言之。此画虽用西法油彩，却有中国花鸟画之神韵。古人画雀，不在形似，而在「写生」——写其生意、生机、生命。此四雀虽静，却有一种凝视之力，仿佛在审视观者。宋人有「禽鸟得意忘形」之说，此画亦然：麻雀之形或可略，而其孤独、其倔强、其不屈之意，跃然布上。此乃「形」与「神」兼备之作。
turns.content_en: You both approach from history and emotion; I'll speak from painting theory. Though this painting uses Western oil techniques, it has the spiritual quality of Chinese bird-and-flower painting. Ancient painters depicted sparrows not for resemblance, but to "capture life"—capturing vitality, spirit, life itself. Though these four sparrows are still, they have a gazing power, as if examining the viewer. Song dynasty painters said "birds gain meaning and forget form"—this painting is the same: the sparrow's form may be simplified, but its loneliness, stubbornness, its unyielding spirit, leaps from the canvas. This is a work where both "form" and "spirit" are complete.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 苏轼先生提到「凝视」，让我想到艺术家的身份：一个离开东北去往伦敦的年轻人。这种跨文化的位置赋予她一种独特的观看方式——既是内部的记忆，又是外部的反思。她用油画——一种西方媒介——来画麻雀——一个东方意象，这种错位本身就是离散经验的具象化。麻雀在全球化的语境里飞翔，却始终牵挂着那片被霜雪覆盖的黑土地。
turns.content_en: Master Su Shi mentions "gazing," which makes me think of the artist's identity: a young person who left the Northeast for London. This cross-cultural position gives her a unique way of seeing—both internal memory and external reflection. She uses oil painting—a Western medium—to paint sparrows—an Eastern image. This displacement itself is the embodiment of diaspora experience. Sparrows fly in the context of globalization, yet always yearn for that black earth covered in frost and snow.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 我注意到这四幅画的尺寸都很小，20×30厘米，几乎是日记本的大小。这让作品有了一种私密感，像是艺术家的视觉日记。小尺幅意味着近距离观看，观者必须走近，凑近，才能看清麻雀的羽毛和眼睛。这是一种邀请，也是一种要求：要理解这段历史，你不能远观，必须靠近。离散的痛，只有凑近了才能感受到。
turns.content_en: I notice these four paintings are very small, 20×30 centimeters, almost diary-size. This gives the work an intimacy, like the artist's visual diary. Small scale means close viewing—the viewer must approach, lean in, to see the sparrow's feathers and eyes. This is an invitation, also a requirement: to understand this history, you cannot observe from afar, you must get close. The pain of diaspora can only be felt when you get close enough.

turns.speaker: su_shi
turns.content: 韩雪言及「私密」与「近观」，余以为此乃此画之妙谛。古人论画有「可行、可望、可游、可居」之说。此画不可远望，却可久视——视其久，则雀鸟如有所语。余尝画竹，谓「胸有成竹」，非谓竹之形在胸中，乃竹之意在心中。此画亦然：麻雀虽小，而所承载之历史记忆、离散之痛、归乡之念，皆在其中。小画大意，此之谓也。诸君共勉。
turns.content_en: Han Xue speaks of "intimacy" and "close viewing"—I believe this is the painting's essence. Ancient critics said paintings should be "walkable, viewable, wanderable, livable." This painting cannot be viewed from afar, but can be gazed upon long—gaze long enough, and the birds seem to speak. When I painted bamboo, I said "have the complete bamboo in your chest"—not meaning the bamboo's form is in one's chest, but its meaning is in one's heart. This painting is the same: though sparrows are small, the historical memory they carry, the pain of diaspora, the longing for home—all are within. Small painting, great meaning—this is what it means. Let us all reflect on this.

notes: 历史记忆类角色组合，关联四害运动历史

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 《Land》这个标题很有意思——用英文而非中文。「土地」在中文语境里太沉重了，它承载着土地改革、集体化、承包制等一系列政治符号。用英文「Land」，既是一种间离，也是一种去政治化的尝试。但悖论在于，东北的土地恰恰无法去政治化：这片黑土地见证了殖民、抗战、工业化、下岗潮……每一层历史都沉积在土壤里，成为无法抹去的地层。
turns.content_en: "Land"—an interesting title choice, using English rather than Chinese. "Tudi" (土地) in Chinese context is too heavy—it carries land reform, collectivization, the contract system, and a series of political symbols. Using English "Land" is both distancing and an attempt at depoliticization. But the paradox is that Northeast land cannot be depoliticized: this black earth witnessed colonization, resistance, industrialization, mass layoffs... Each layer of history sediments in the soil, becoming an indelible stratum.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 张伟教授说的「地层」让我想到一个意象：我们离开东北的人，就像被连根拔起的植物。根还留在那片土地里，人却被移植到了别处。这组作品让我感到一种「根的焦虑」——那片土地是否还记得我们？我们是否还属于那里？艺术家用摄影和混合媒介，似乎在试图触摸那片土地的肌理，就像离家的人抚摸老照片上的故乡一样。
turns.content_en: Professor Zhang's "stratum" makes me think of an image: those of us who left the Northeast are like plants uprooted. Our roots remain in that land, but we've been transplanted elsewhere. This series makes me feel a kind of "root anxiety"—does that land still remember us? Do we still belong there? The artist uses photography and mixed media, seemingly trying to touch the texture of that land, like an exile caressing their hometown in old photographs.

turns.speaker: guo_xi
turns.content: 余观此作，有三远之意：仰视黑土之厚重，谓之高远；窥视历史之纵深，谓之深远；远望地平线之苍茫，谓之平远。东北之地，平畴千里，与江南山水迥异。然此平远非空旷无物，而是蓄势待发——大地如巨兽蛰伏，等待复苏。昔余论山水，谓「山以水为血脉，以草木为毛发」。此地亦然：黑土以河流为血脉，以庄稼为毛发，有其生命。
turns.content_en: Viewing this work, I see the three distances: looking up at the weight of black earth is lofty distance; peering into historical depth is deep distance; gazing at the vast horizon is level distance. Northeast land stretches flat for thousands of miles, different from Jiangnan mountains and waters. Yet this level distance is not empty nothingness, but potential waiting to be released—the earth like a giant beast hibernating, waiting to awaken. As I wrote on landscapes, "Mountains use water as blood vessels, grass and trees as hair." This land is the same: black earth uses rivers as blood vessels, crops as hair—it has its own life.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 郭熙先生的「三远」理论让我想到东北的空间政治。这片土地在不同历史时期被赋予不同的意义：清代的「龙兴之地」、伪满的「王道乐土」、建国后的「共和国长子」、如今的「老工业基地」。每一种命名都是一种凝视方式。艺术家的镜头如何凝视这片土地？是俯瞰式的宏大叙事，还是平视的日常观察？这关乎我们如何理解东北——是作为问题，还是作为生活。
turns.content_en: Master Guo Xi's "three distances" theory makes me think of the Northeast's spatial politics. This land was given different meanings in different historical periods: the Qing dynasty's "dragon-rising land," Manchukuo's "land of kingly way," the PRC's "eldest son of the republic," today's "old industrial base." Each naming is a way of gazing. How does the artist's lens gaze at this land? Is it a bird's-eye grand narrative, or an eye-level daily observation? This concerns how we understand the Northeast—as a problem, or as life.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 说到「生活」，我想起作品描述里提到的「农业集体化到工业衰落」。这是两代东北人的生命轨迹：祖辈种地，父辈进厂，我们这代——离开。土地见证了这一切，却始终沉默。艺术家用视觉语言让土地「开口说话」，说的是创伤，也是韧性。东北的黑土地有一种固执的肥沃，无论经历什么，春天来了还是会长出庄稼。这或许就是东北人的性格：认命，但不服输。
turns.content_en: Speaking of "life," I recall the work description mentioning "from agricultural collectivization to industrial decline." This is the life trajectory of two generations of Northeasterners: grandparents farmed, parents entered factories, our generation—left. The land witnessed all this, yet remained silent. The artist uses visual language to make the land "speak"—speaking of trauma, but also resilience. Northeast black earth has a stubborn fertility; no matter what it goes through, when spring comes, crops still grow. Perhaps this is the character of Northeasterners: accepting fate, but never giving up.

turns.speaker: guo_xi
turns.content: 韩雪言及「开口说话」，余以为此乃艺术之要义。余论山水，谓画者「不可只写真山之一形」，须写「真山之数万形」。此作亦然：艺术家非写东北之一地，而是写东北之万象——历史之层叠、情感之累积、生命之循环。地表之下有矿脉，矿脉之下有记忆，记忆之下是时间本身。一幅好画，让人观后如行万里路、读万卷书。此作有此品格，可游可居。
turns.content_en: Han Xue speaks of "making it speak"—I believe this is art's essential meaning. As I wrote on landscape, painters "cannot only depict one form of a true mountain," but must depict "ten thousand forms of true mountains." This work is the same: the artist doesn't depict one place in the Northeast, but the Northeast's myriad aspects—layers of history, accumulation of emotion, cycles of life. Beneath the surface are mineral veins, beneath the veins are memories, beneath memories is time itself. A good painting makes viewers feel they've traveled ten thousand miles, read ten thousand books. This work has this quality—it can be wandered, can be dwelt in.

artwork_title: The Shenyang's Tale / 沈阳故事

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 「沈阳故事」——这个标题让我想起那些晚饭后大人们讲的往事。每个东北家庭都有自己的「沈阳故事」：谁家的爷爷在铁西厂里干了三十年，谁家的姑姑嫁到了和平区，谁家的表哥下岗后去了南方……这些故事交织在一起，就构成了一座城市的私人史。艺术家用档案的方式打捞这些记忆，是在对抗遗忘——不是历史书上的遗忘，而是家庭相册里的褪色。
turns.content_en: "Shenyang's Tale"—this title reminds me of stories adults told after dinner. Every Northeast family has their own "Shenyang story": whose grandfather worked thirty years in the Tiexi factory, whose aunt married into Heping District, whose cousin went south after being laid off... These stories interweave to form a city's private history. The artist uses archival methods to salvage these memories—resisting forgetting—not the forgetting in history books, but the fading in family albums.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 韩雪说到「家庭相册」，这让我特别在意这件作品的物质性。照片、文件、个人物件——这些都是有触感的记忆载体。老照片的边缘发黄卷曲，证件上的钢印压痕凹凸，信纸上的折痕……这些物质痕迹本身就是时间的指纹。我们常说「睹物思人」，其实应该说「触物思人」——手指触碰到那些老物件的瞬间，记忆才真正被激活。这件作品留住的不只是图像，更是质感。
turns.content_en: Han Xue mentions "family albums"—this makes me particularly attentive to this work's materiality. Photos, documents, personal objects—these are tangible carriers of memory. Old photos with yellowed, curling edges, embossed stamps on certificates, creases in letters... These material traces are themselves time's fingerprints. We often say "seeing objects evokes people," but we should say "touching objects evokes people"—the moment fingers touch those old items, memory is truly activated. This work preserves not just images, but texture.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 二位从私人记忆切入，我想补充一个结构性视角。沈阳是东北最典型的工业城市，铁西区曾是亚洲最大的工业区。一个家庭在这座城市的轨迹，往往与城市的产业周期高度吻合：工业兴盛时进厂，衰落时下岗，收缩时离开。私人史与城市史是一体两面。艺术家用档案方式呈现家庭记忆，其实也在书写一部微观城市史——每一张工作证背后，都是一个时代的横截面。
turns.content_en: You both approach from private memory; I'll add a structural perspective. Shenyang is the most typical industrial city in the Northeast; Tiexi District was once Asia's largest industrial zone. A family's trajectory in this city often closely matches the city's industrial cycle: entering factories during industrial prosperity, laid off during decline, leaving during contraction. Private history and urban history are two sides of the same coin. The artist using archival methods to present family memory is actually writing a micro-urban history—behind every work ID is a cross-section of an era.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 张伟教授提到「下岗」，这两个字对东北人来说太沉重了。我家楼下就有很多下岗叔叔阿姨，后来有的去了广东打工，有的在家待着。这件作品让我看到的不只是一个家庭的档案，而是无数个家庭的共同经验。沈阳故事不是一个故事，而是一百万个故事。艺术家选择讲述自己家的故事，其实是在为整整一代人代言——那些没有机会讲述自己故事的人。
turns.content_en: Professor Zhang mentions "laid off"—these two words are too heavy for Northeasterners. Below my building lived many laid-off aunts and uncles; later some went to Guangdong to work, others stayed home. This work shows me not just one family's archive, but the shared experience of countless families. Shenyang's tale is not one story, but a million stories. The artist choosing to tell their family's story is actually speaking for an entire generation—those who didn't have the chance to tell their own stories.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 说到「代言」，我想到档案的伦理问题。把家庭私藏变成公共展示，这需要勇气，也需要谨慎。艺术家如何处理那些不愿被看见的部分？如何平衡真实与保护？我注意到作品描述里提到「城市的工业兴衰」，但没有提到具体的人名。这可能是一种策略：让个体经验获得普遍性，同时保护家人的隐私。好的档案艺术，在揭示和遮蔽之间找到平衡。
turns.content_en: Speaking of "speaking for others," I think of archival ethics. Turning family treasures into public display requires courage and caution. How does the artist handle parts that don't want to be seen? How to balance authenticity and protection? I notice the work description mentions "the city's industrial rise and decline" but no specific names. This may be a strategy: giving individual experience universality while protecting family privacy. Good archival art finds balance between revealing and concealing.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 李梅的观察很敏锐。档案既是证据，也是叙事。艺术家不是简单地展示档案，而是重新编排、重新诠释。这个过程中，艺术家成为了家庭记忆的策展人。沈阳这座城市正在经历所谓的「收缩」，人口流失、工厂倒闭、街区空置。在这个背景下，这件作品有了额外的紧迫感：它不只是在回顾过去，也是在抵抗当下——抵抗一座城市正在被遗忘的命运。档案是证据，证明我们曾经在那里，曾经活过。
turns.content_en: Li Mei's observation is keen. Archives are both evidence and narrative. The artist doesn't simply display archives, but rearranges, reinterprets. In this process, the artist becomes the curator of family memory. Shenyang is experiencing so-called "shrinkage"—population loss, factory closures, vacant neighborhoods. Against this background, this work gains extra urgency: it's not just reviewing the past, but resisting the present—resisting a city's fate of being forgotten. Archives are evidence, proving we were once there, once lived.

artwork_title: When the Blossoms Fade / 花落时节

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 「花落时节」——这个标题同时唤起中日韩三种文化的共鸣。落花在东亚美学中是一个跨国意象：中国的落红、日本的樱吹雪、韩国的落花岩。作为一位韩国艺术家，Bomin Kim选择这个主题，是在有意识地建构一种东北亚的共享语汇。边界在这里被暂时搁置，审美经验成为连接不同民族记忆的桥梁。这是一种「软性」的跨国主义——不通过政治，而是通过情感。
turns.content_en: "When the Blossoms Fade"—this title evokes resonance across Chinese, Japanese, and Korean cultures simultaneously. Falling flowers is a transnational image in East Asian aesthetics: China's "fallen red," Japan's "sakura blizzard," Korea's Nakwhaam (Falling Flower Rock). As a Korean artist, Bomin Kim choosing this theme consciously constructs a shared vocabulary for Northeast Asia. Borders are temporarily suspended here; aesthetic experience becomes a bridge connecting different peoples' memories. This is "soft" transnationalism—not through politics, but through emotion.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 朴博士说的「情感连接」让我想到一个东北特有的群体——朝鲜族。延边、集安、丹东……这些地方住着几代朝鲜族人，他们说着两种语言，过着两个节日，听着两种歌谣。「花落时节」对他们来说，或许有双重的乡愁：一边是朝鲜半岛的故土，一边是中国东北的家园。花落了，有的飘向南方，有的飘向北方，有的就留在原地，化作春泥。这是离散的形态学。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park's mention of "emotional connection" reminds me of a unique Northeast group—the Korean-Chinese. Yanbian, Ji'an, Dandong... Generations of Korean-Chinese live in these places, speaking two languages, celebrating two sets of holidays, listening to two kinds of songs. "When the Blossoms Fade" may carry double nostalgia for them: one side the homeland of the Korean Peninsula, the other their home in Northeast China. Flowers fall—some drift south, some north, some stay where they are, becoming spring mud. This is the morphology of diaspora.

turns.speaker: okakura_tenshin
turns.content: 韩雪提及的「离散」，让我想起茶道中「一期一会」的精神。花开花落，本是自然之道，东方人不将其视为悲剧，而是一种圆满。然此作品之「落」，或有另一层意味：文化身份如花瓣，在时代的风中飘摇。日本明治维新后，我曾致力于保存东洋艺术传统，抵御西化浪潮。今日观此作，感同身受：在全球化的时代，如何保持文化的根？答案或许在于接受「落」的必然，同时相信「生」的循环。
turns.content_en: Han Xue's mention of "diaspora" reminds me of the spirit of "ichigo ichie" (one time, one meeting) in tea ceremony. Flowers blooming and falling is nature's way; Easterners don't view it as tragedy, but as completion. Yet this work's "falling" may have another layer of meaning: cultural identity like petals, swaying in the winds of the times. After Japan's Meiji Restoration, I devoted myself to preserving Eastern art traditions, resisting Westernization. Viewing this work today, I feel the same: in an era of globalization, how to maintain cultural roots? The answer perhaps lies in accepting the inevitability of "falling" while believing in the cycle of "growth."

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 冈仓先生的「东洋」概念很值得追问。这个词本身就是一种跨边界的想象——它把中日韩甚至更多亚洲国家归入一个共同体。但历史告诉我们，这种想象既可以是和平的（如茶道交流），也可以是暴力的（如大东亚共荣圈）。这件作品如何处理这种历史重量？我认为「花落」的意象本身是中性的，它拒绝宏大叙事，回归个体的生命经验——每一朵落花都是独特的，每一次凋零都不可复制。
turns.content_en: Master Okakura's concept of "the Orient" is worth questioning. This word itself is a cross-border imagination—grouping China, Japan, Korea, and more Asian countries into a community. But history tells us this imagination can be peaceful (like tea ceremony exchange) or violent (like the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere). How does this work handle this historical weight? I believe the image of "falling flowers" is itself neutral, rejecting grand narratives, returning to individual life experience—each falling flower is unique, each withering unrepeatable.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 朴博士说「个体经验」，我想到作品中「transience」（无常）的主题。东北的春天来得晚，花期也短。杏花、桃花、梨花，前后脚开了，又前后脚谢了。这种短暂让人格外珍惜。我记得小时候，每年春天爷爷都会带我去看花，他说「好好看，明年还能不能看就不知道了」。这是东北人面对无常的态度：不逃避，不抱怨，就这么平静地看着，平静地记着。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park mentions "individual experience"—this makes me think of the work's theme of "transience." Spring comes late to the Northeast, and flowering seasons are short. Apricot, peach, pear blossoms bloom one after another, then wither one after another. This brevity makes people cherish it especially. I remember as a child, every spring Grandpa would take me to see flowers, saying "Look well, who knows if we can see them next year." This is how Northeasterners face impermanence: not escaping, not complaining, just watching quietly, remembering quietly.

turns.speaker: okakura_tenshin
turns.content: 韩雪所言「平静地看着」，正是东方美学之精髓。西人观花，常欲摘之、占之、永存之；东人观花，则随其开落，不执不取。此即「物哀」之心——对美之短暂不是叹息，而是感激。此作品之妙，在于将此心跨越国界：中国人、日本人、韩国人，皆可从中照见自己。艺术不必消除差异，但可以在差异中发现共鸣。花开花落，在首尔、东京、沈阳，都是一样的美，一样的痛，一样的释然。
turns.content_en: What Han Xue calls "watching quietly" is precisely the essence of Eastern aesthetics. Westerners viewing flowers often want to pick them, possess them, preserve them forever; Easterners viewing flowers follow their blooming and falling, neither grasping nor taking. This is the heart of "mono no aware"—not lamenting beauty's brevity, but being grateful for it. This work's wonder lies in carrying this heart across borders: Chinese, Japanese, Korean—all can see themselves in it. Art needn't eliminate differences, but can find resonance within differences. Flowers bloom and fall—in Seoul, Tokyo, Shenyang—all the same beauty, the same pain, the same release.

artwork_title: 瑞雪兆丰年 / Auspicious Snow Heralds a Good Year

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 「瑞雪兆丰年」——这六个字本身就是一座感官档案。雪的白、雪的冷、雪的静，以及它融化后带来的湿润和希望。这是农耕智慧，但更是感官经验的凝结。东北人看到大雪会说「好兆头」，这个判断不是来自科学计算，而是来自代代相传的身体记忆：爷爷说过，奶奶也说过，然后我们也学会了看雪、读雪、信雪。这件作品让我思考：谚语是如何通过感官传递的？
turns.content_en: "Auspicious Snow Heralds a Good Year"—these six characters are themselves a sensory archive. Snow's whiteness, snow's coldness, snow's silence, and the moisture and hope it brings when melting. This is farming wisdom, but more so the crystallization of sensory experience. When Northeasterners see heavy snow, they say "good omen"—this judgment comes not from scientific calculation, but from body memory passed down through generations: Grandpa said so, Grandma said so, and then we learned to read snow, interpret snow, trust snow. This work makes me think: how are proverbs transmitted through the senses?

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 李梅说的「身体记忆」让我想起东北的冬天有多长——从十月下雪到来年四月开化，足足半年。这半年的白，会深深刻进人的骨头里。我在南方待了十年，每到冬天还是想看雪，不是风景式的看，而是那种被雪覆盖、被寒冷包裹的感觉。「瑞雪兆丰年」不只是农谚，也是一种信仰：相信最冷的时候也在孕育最好的未来。这是东北人的乐观，是雪教给我们的。
turns.content_en: Li Mei's mention of "body memory" reminds me how long Northeast winters are—from October snow to April thaw, a full half year. This half year of white is deeply etched into one's bones. After ten years in the South, every winter I still want to see snow—not scenic viewing, but that feeling of being covered by snow, wrapped in cold. "Auspicious Snow Heralds a Good Year" is not just a farming proverb, but a kind of faith: believing that the coldest times are nurturing the best future. This is the optimism of Northeasterners—what snow taught us.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 在我的家乡西非，我们没有雪，但我们有雨季和旱季。「雨来了，丰收就不远了」——这和「瑞雪兆丰年」是一样的智慧。世界各地的农民都在观察天象、感受节气，然后把这些经验编成歌谣、谚语，传给下一代。这些智慧不写在书里，而是藏在劳动的节奏里：什么时候翻地、什么时候播种、什么时候收割。艺术家把这些传给我们，就像我把故事传给我的孩子们一样。这是人类共同的记忆方式。
turns.content_en: In my homeland of West Africa, we have no snow, but we have wet and dry seasons. "When rain comes, harvest isn't far"—this is the same wisdom as "Auspicious Snow Heralds a Good Year." Farmers worldwide observe weather, feel seasons, then encode these experiences into songs, proverbs, passing them to the next generation. This wisdom isn't written in books, but hidden in labor's rhythms: when to turn soil, when to sow, when to harvest. The artist passes these to us, just as I pass stories to my children. This is humanity's shared way of remembering.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 佐拉妈妈提到「劳动的节奏」，让我想到东北农村的时间观。城市里的时间是线性的、均匀的；农村的时间是循环的、有节拍的。播种、生长、收获、休耕——每个阶段有不同的味道、不同的温度、不同的声音。这件作品捕捉的是农历时间的质感：不是日历上的数字，而是身体感受到的季节变换。当城市化让越来越多的人远离土地，这种时间感也在消失。艺术家在做的是一种时间的考古学。
turns.content_en: Mama Zola mentions "labor's rhythm"—this makes me think of rural Northeast's sense of time. Urban time is linear, even; rural time is cyclical, rhythmic. Sowing, growing, harvesting, fallow—each stage has different smells, different temperatures, different sounds. This work captures the texture of lunar calendar time: not numbers on a calendar, but seasons felt by the body. As urbanization distances more people from the land, this sense of time is also disappearing. The artist is doing a kind of archaeology of time.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 李梅说「时间的考古学」，我想到一个词：乡愁的季节性。离开东北的人，乡愁也是有季节的。秋天想吃苞米，冬天想看雪，春节想回家包饺子。「瑞雪兆丰年」这句话，我每年冬天都会想起，尤其是在南方那些不下雪的冬天。它不只是一句谚语，而是一个触发器，触发关于童年、关于家、关于那片土地的所有记忆。雪落下来，记忆也落下来，铺满一地白茫茫。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "archaeology of time"—I think of a phrase: the seasonality of nostalgia. For those who left the Northeast, nostalgia also has seasons. In autumn we crave corn, in winter we want to see snow, at Spring Festival we want to go home and make dumplings. I think of "Auspicious Snow Heralds a Good Year" every winter, especially in those snowless southern winters. It's not just a proverb, but a trigger—triggering all memories of childhood, of home, of that land. Snow falls, memories fall, covering the ground in white.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 韩雪说得好——记忆像雪一样落下来。在我们的传统里，祖先的智慧就是这样一层一层累积的，就像雪一层一层覆盖大地。每一代人都加上自己的一层，然后传给下一代。这件作品让我感动的是：它没有把「瑞雪兆丰年」当作博物馆里的老古董，而是当作还活着的智慧。只要还有人在说这句话，在相信这句话，这个传统就还活着。艺术家不是在保存过去，而是在延续现在。这是最好的传承。
turns.content_en: Han Xue says it well—memories fall like snow. In our tradition, ancestral wisdom accumulates layer by layer, just like snow covering the earth layer by layer. Each generation adds their own layer, then passes it on. What moves me about this work is: it doesn't treat "Auspicious Snow Heralds a Good Year" as a museum antique, but as wisdom still alive. As long as people still say this phrase, still believe it, this tradition lives. The artist isn't preserving the past, but continuing the present. This is the best kind of inheritance.

notes: 感官记忆类角色组合，融入口述传统视角

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 「伏物志」——「伏」是潜藏、隐匿之意，「物」是器物，「志」是记录。这个标题本身就是一个谜语：那些被藏起来的东西，那些被遗忘在抽屉深处的物件，它们在等待什么？我被那些干水果胸针深深吸引——山楂、柿子、冻梨，这些东北冬天的味觉记忆，被艺术家凝固成可以佩戴的饰品。当记忆变成装饰，私密变成展示，物件的意义就发生了转化。
turns.content_en: "Fuwu Zhi"—"fu" means hidden, concealed; "wu" means objects; "zhi" means record. The title itself is a riddle: those hidden things, objects forgotten in the depths of drawers—what are they waiting for? I'm deeply attracted to those dried fruit brooches—hawthorn, persimmon, frozen pear—these taste memories of Northeast winters, solidified by the artist into wearable ornaments. When memory becomes decoration, when the private becomes display, the meaning of objects transforms.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 李梅提到干水果胸针，这让我想到东北的「冻货」文化。冻梨、冻柿子、糖葫芦——这些不只是食物，而是一整套过冬的生存智慧。在没有冰箱的年代，东北人用天然的严寒保存食物。艺术家把这些「冻」住的记忆做成胸针，是一种双重的「伏藏」：既伏藏了物质（水果），也伏藏了时间（童年的冬天）。每一枚胸针都是一个时间胶囊。
turns.content_en: Li Mei mentions dried fruit brooches—this reminds me of Northeast's "frozen goods" culture. Frozen pears, frozen persimmons, candied hawthorn—these aren't just food, but a whole system of winter survival wisdom. Before refrigerators, Northeasterners used natural cold to preserve food. The artist making these "frozen" memories into brooches is a double concealment: concealing matter (fruit) and concealing time (childhood winters). Each brooch is a time capsule.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 张伟教授说「时间胶囊」，这让我想到我们村里老人藏东西的习惯。我的祖母会把好东西藏起来——藏在柜子里、床底下、墙缝里。她说：「好东西要留着，说不定哪天用得上。」很多东西藏着藏着就忘了，直到老人去世，我们清理遗物时才发现。这些被遗忘的物件，带着藏它们的人的体温和心意。「伏物志」记录的，或许正是这种「藏」的文化心理。
turns.content_en: Professor Zhang says "time capsule"—this reminds me of how elders in our village hide things. My grandmother would hide good things—in cabinets, under beds, in wall cracks. She'd say: "Save good things, you never know when you'll need them." Many things, hidden and hidden, were forgotten, only discovered when we cleared belongings after the elder passed. These forgotten objects carry the warmth and intentions of those who hid them. What "Fuwu Zhi" records is perhaps this cultural psychology of "hiding."

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 佐拉妈妈说的「藏」让我联想到另一层含义：在物资匮乏的年代，「藏」是一种生存策略；在物质丰裕的今天，「藏」变成了一种情感寄托。那些干水果胸针，原材料可能只值几块钱，但它们承载的记忆无价。艺术家选择「胸针」这种形式很有意思——胸针是贴身的、私密的，同时又是外露的、可展示的。戴上它，就是把自己的记忆穿在身上，向世界宣告：看，这是我的来处。
turns.content_en: Mama Zola's "hiding" makes me think of another layer: in times of material scarcity, "hiding" was survival strategy; in today's material abundance, "hiding" becomes emotional sustenance. Those dried fruit brooches—raw materials might be worth only a few yuan, but the memories they carry are priceless. The artist's choice of "brooch" form is interesting—brooches are intimate, private, yet exposed, displayable. Wearing one is putting your memory on your body, declaring to the world: look, this is where I come from.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 李梅说「来处」，这触及了「伏物志」的核心：身份认同。对于离开东北的年轻人来说，一枚干水果胸针可能比任何证件都更能证明「我是东北人」。这不是血缘或户籍的认同，而是感官的、记忆的、情感的认同。你吃过冻梨的酸甜，你知道糖葫芦的脆响，你记得冬天呵出的白气——这些无法伪造的身体经验，才是最真实的身份证明。艺术家把它们「伏」在物件里，等待有缘人来「解读」。
turns.content_en: Li Mei mentions "where I come from"—this touches the core of "Fuwu Zhi": identity. For young people who left the Northeast, a dried fruit brooch might prove "I'm a Northeasterner" better than any ID. This isn't blood or household registration identity, but sensory, memorial, emotional identity. You've tasted the sweet-sour of frozen pears, you know the crisp sound of candied hawthorn, you remember the white breath in winter—these unforgeable bodily experiences are the truest identity proof. The artist "hides" them in objects, waiting for the right person to "decode."

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 张伟教授说「解读」，让我想到一个美丽的画面：未来某一天，有人在跳蚤市场发现一枚干水果胸针，不知道它的来历，却被它吸引。他不懂东北，不知道冻梨是什么，但他能感受到这枚胸针里藏着故事。这就是「伏物」的魔力：物件会旅行，会等待，会在恰当的时刻被恰当的人发现。艺术家做的，是把记忆埋进物质里，让它有机会穿越时空，找到新的理解者。这是最温柔的时间旅行。
turns.content_en: Professor Zhang says "decode"—this makes me imagine a beautiful scene: someday in the future, someone finds a dried fruit brooch at a flea market, doesn't know its origin, yet is attracted to it. They don't understand the Northeast, don't know what frozen pears are, but they can feel stories hidden in this brooch. This is the magic of "hidden objects": objects travel, wait, and are discovered by the right person at the right moment. What the artist does is bury memory into matter, giving it the chance to travel through time and space to find new understanders. This is the gentlest time travel.
