turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 「噪音」是一个有趣的隐喻：它既是物理现象，也是社会现象。在声学里，噪音是无序的信号；在政治里，噪音是被边缘化的声音。这件声音装置让我思考：谁有权定义什么是「噪音」？移民的语言、方言的腔调、异乡的口音——这些常常被主流社会视为「噪音」。艺术家选择拥抱噪音，而不是追求「纯净」的声音，这本身就是一种政治姿态。
turns.content_en: "Noise" is an interesting metaphor: it's both a physical phenomenon and a social one. In acoustics, noise is disordered signals; in politics, noise is marginalized voices. This sound installation makes me think: who has the right to define what is "noise"? Immigrants' languages, dialectal accents, foreign tongues—these are often viewed as "noise" by mainstream society. The artist choosing to embrace noise, rather than pursuing "pure" sound, is itself a political stance.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 朴博士从政治角度切入，我想补充感官层面。噪音最直接的特点是它让人不舒服——刺耳、杂乱、无法忽略。但这恰恰是离散经验的真实质感：不是浪漫化的乡愁，而是真实的焦虑和不适。飞机的引擎声、火车站的广播、陌生城市的方言——这些都是移动中的噪音。艺术家没有过滤这些声音，而是层叠它们，让观者感受那种被声音包围却听不懂任何一个的孤独。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park approaches from politics; I'll add the sensory dimension. Noise's most direct characteristic is that it's uncomfortable—harsh, chaotic, impossible to ignore. But this is precisely the authentic texture of diaspora experience: not romanticized nostalgia, but real anxiety and discomfort. Airplane engines, train station announcements, unfamiliar city dialects—these are the noises of movement. The artist doesn't filter these sounds, but layers them, letting viewers feel that loneliness of being surrounded by sounds yet understanding none.

turns.speaker: prof_elena_petrova
turns.content: 从形式主义角度看，「噪音」作为艺术材料本身就是一种「陌生化」策略。我们通常把声音分为「有意义的」和「没意义的」——音乐、语言属于前者，噪音属于后者。但这件作品模糊了这一边界：噪音不再是背景，而是主角。这让观者重新审听那些被忽略的声音。什克洛夫斯基说艺术要让石头更像石头，这件作品让噪音更像噪音——暴露其物质性、偶然性、不可控性。
turns.content_en: From a Formalist perspective, "noise" as artistic material is itself a "defamiliarization" strategy. We usually divide sounds into "meaningful" and "meaningless"—music and language belong to the former, noise to the latter. But this work blurs that boundary: noise is no longer background, but protagonist. This makes viewers re-hear those ignored sounds. Shklovsky said art should make the stone more stony; this work makes noise more noisy—exposing its materiality, contingency, uncontrollability.

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 彼得罗娃教授提到「不可控性」，这让我想到边境的声音。边境是噪音最密集的地方：海关的敲章声、安检机的嗡鸣、多语种的广播……这些声音标记着主权的边界——跨过这条线，声音环境就变了。艺术家用声音装置模拟这种边境体验，让观者在安全的展览空间里体验那种「穿越」的感觉。这是一种身体性的跨国主义——不通过护照，而是通过耳朵。
turns.content_en: Professor Petrova mentions "uncontrollability"—this makes me think of border sounds. Borders are where noise is densest: customs stamps, security scanner hums, multilingual announcements... These sounds mark sovereign boundaries—cross this line, and the sound environment changes. The artist uses sound installation to simulate this border experience, letting viewers in safe exhibition space experience that feeling of "crossing." This is embodied transnationalism—not through passports, but through ears.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 说到「身体性」，我注意到作品描述里提到了「fragmented experience」（碎片化体验）。噪音的特点就是无法被整合成连贯的叙事——它们是片段的、偶然的、相互干扰的。这很像移民的记忆：不是一条线性的时间轴，而是一堆散落的声音碎片。某一刻的汽车喇叭、某一天的雨声、某一个不认识的人的咳嗽——这些都被记住了，却无法被讲述。噪音是那些无法讲述的记忆的载体。
turns.content_en: Speaking of "embodiment," I notice the work description mentions "fragmented experience." Noise's characteristic is that it cannot be integrated into coherent narrative—it's fragmentary, contingent, mutually interfering. This is like immigrant memory: not a linear timeline, but a pile of scattered sound fragments. A car horn at some moment, rain on some day, a stranger's cough—all remembered, yet cannot be told. Noise is the carrier of memories that cannot be told.

turns.speaker: prof_elena_petrova
turns.content: 李梅说「无法讲述」，我想到雅各布森的「诗性功能」理论。诗歌的力量不在于它说了什么，而在于它如何说。噪音也是如此：它不传达信息，但它创造氛围、引发情感、触发记忆。这件作品的「内容」是空的——没有故事、没有人物、没有情节。但它的「形式」是满的——声波、频率、节奏、层次。这是声音的诗学：用噪音写诗，用干扰作曲。观者不是在「理解」作品，而是在「经历」作品。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "cannot be told"—I think of Jakobson's "poetic function" theory. Poetry's power lies not in what it says, but how it says it. Noise is the same: it doesn't convey information, but creates atmosphere, triggers emotion, activates memory. This work's "content" is empty—no story, no characters, no plot. But its "form" is full—sound waves, frequencies, rhythms, layers. This is the poetics of sound: writing poetry with noise, composing with interference. Viewers aren't "understanding" the work, but "experiencing" it.

notes: 声音艺术，融入形式主义理论视角

artwork_title: Northeast Asia Memory / 东北亚记忆

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 「东北亚记忆」——这个标题把「东北」从中国的一个地区扩展为一个跨国区域。东北亚不只是中国东北，还包括朝鲜半岛、日本、俄罗斯远东。这些地方有共同的气候记忆：漫长的冬天、暴风雪、冰冻的河流。当我想到东北亚，首先想到的是「冷」——那种渗进骨头的冷。这件多感官装置如何传递这种跨边界的寒意？触觉和温度或许是最有效的语言。
turns.content_en: "Northeast Asia Memory"—this title expands "Northeast" from a region of China to a transnational area. Northeast Asia is not just China's Northeast, but also the Korean Peninsula, Japan, Russian Far East. These places share climatic memories: long winters, blizzards, frozen rivers. When I think of Northeast Asia, I first think of "cold"—that cold that seeps into bones. How does this multi-sensory installation convey this cross-border chill? Touch and temperature may be the most effective language.

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 李梅说「跨边界的寒意」很有意思。气候不认国界——鹿儿岛的雪和哈尔滨的雪是一样冷的。但历史认国界：满洲国的殖民记忆、朝鲜战争的创伤、中苏分裂的对峙……这些边界把共同的自然经验切割成不同的政治记忆。这件作品的野心在于：能否用感官体验来弥合历史的裂痕？让观者不是通过知识，而是通过身体，感受到那片土地的共同性。这是一种「感官政治」的尝试。
turns.content_en: Li Mei's "cross-border chill" is interesting. Climate doesn't recognize borders—snow in Kagoshima is as cold as snow in Harbin. But history recognizes borders: Manchukuo's colonial memory, Korean War trauma, Sino-Soviet split confrontation... These borders cut shared natural experience into different political memories. This work's ambition is: can sensory experience bridge historical rifts? Let viewers feel that land's commonality not through knowledge, but through body. This is an attempt at "sensory politics."

turns.speaker: okakura_tenshin
turns.content: 朴博士言及「感官政治」，余以为此乃东方艺术之本义。东方人不以理性分析自然，而以身体感应自然。禅宗有言「冷暖自知」，非言语所能传达。东北亚这片土地，虽被国界分割，然其山川风土一脉相承。余昔年在波士顿美术馆，常思如何向西方人解释东方艺术之精神。此作品或可作为一种示范：不讲道理，只造体验；不说历史，只触感官。这是艺术可以做到而政治做不到的事。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park speaks of "sensory politics"—I believe this is Eastern art's essential meaning. Easterners don't analyze nature through reason, but sense nature through body. Zen says "knowing cold and warm for oneself"—beyond what words can convey. This land of Northeast Asia, though divided by borders, has mountains and waters that share one origin. In my years at Boston Museum, I often thought about how to explain Eastern art's spirit to Westerners. This work could serve as demonstration: don't lecture, just create experience; don't tell history, just touch the senses. This is what art can do that politics cannot.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 冈仓先生说「不说历史，只触感官」，但我想补充：感官本身就是历史的载体。当我们触摸一件东北亚的物件——一把朝鲜族的勺子、一块日式的织物、一件俄罗斯的搪瓷杯——我们触摸的不只是材料，还有使用这些物件的无数只手。这件装置如果能唤起这种「触摸的传承」，它就成功了。感官记忆不是抽象的，而是物质化的、可触摸的。正是通过这些物件，历史穿过边界，抵达我们的皮肤。
turns.content_en: Master Okakura says "don't tell history, just touch the senses," but I'd add: the senses themselves carry history. When we touch a Northeast Asian object—a Korean spoon, a Japanese textile, a Russian enamel cup—we touch not just material, but the countless hands that used these objects. If this installation can evoke this "transmission through touch," it succeeds. Sensory memory is not abstract, but materialized, touchable. It's through these objects that history crosses borders, reaching our skin.

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 李梅提到「物件」，让我想到东北亚流动的物质文化：满洲铁路带来的日本商品、朝鲜族移民带来的辣白菜、俄罗斯商人带来的伏特加……这些东西跨越边界，在不同的土地上生根。与其说东北亚是一个地理概念，不如说它是一个物质网络。这件作品的多感官设计，正是试图重建这个网络：让观者同时看到、听到、触到、嗅到来自不同地方的元素，在感官层面上完成一次「穿越」。
turns.content_en: Li Mei mentions "objects"—this makes me think of Northeast Asia's flowing material culture: Japanese goods brought by the South Manchuria Railway, kimchi brought by Korean immigrants, vodka brought by Russian merchants... These things crossed borders, taking root in different lands. Rather than saying Northeast Asia is a geographic concept, it's better to say it's a material network. This work's multi-sensory design is precisely trying to reconstruct this network: letting viewers simultaneously see, hear, touch, smell elements from different places, completing a "crossing" at the sensory level.

turns.speaker: okakura_tenshin
turns.content: 朴博士言「物质网络」，余深以为然。余昔年著《东洋的理想》，欲为亚洲寻一精神纽带。今观此作，觉艺术家走的是另一条路：不是理念的统一，而是感官的共鸣。这或许更切实际。理念易生争论，感官难以否认——谁能否认冬天的冷、米饭的香、丝绸的滑？这些感官经验是超越政治的。东北亚的未来，或许不在于谁同意谁，而在于能否一起感受同一场雪、同一阵风、同一片星空。这件作品是一个开始。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park speaks of "material network"—I deeply agree. In my early years I wrote "The Ideals of the East," seeking a spiritual bond for Asia. Viewing this work today, I feel the artist takes another path: not unity of ideas, but resonance of senses. This may be more practical. Ideas easily breed argument; senses are hard to deny—who can deny winter's cold, rice's fragrance, silk's smoothness? These sensory experiences transcend politics. Northeast Asia's future may lie not in who agrees with whom, but in whether we can together feel the same snowfall, the same wind, the same starry sky. This work is a beginning.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 1999——这个年份对我们这代人有特殊意义。世纪末的焦虑和希望交织在一起，Y2K bug的恐慌、千禧年的倒计时、「跨世纪」这个词反复出现在大人的对话里。对于小孩子来说，那是一个充满魔法的时刻：我们将活过两个世纪。艺术家选择这一年作为作品标题，是在打开一个时间胶囊——那个特定年份的气味、声音、质感，以及那时我们对未来的所有想象。
turns.content_en: 1999—this year has special meaning for our generation. End-of-century anxiety and hope intertwined: Y2K bug panic, millennium countdown, "crossing the century" repeated in adults' conversations. For children, it was a magical moment: we would live through two centuries. The artist choosing this year as title is opening a time capsule—that specific year's smells, sounds, textures, and all our imaginations of the future then.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 韩雪说「时间胶囊」，这让我想到1999年的物质文化：VCD、BP机、大哥大、586电脑……这些东西在当时是最前沿的，现在却成了怀旧符号。艺术家用档案材料和个人物件来重建那一年，其实是在重建一个感官生态系统。1999年的东北家庭是什么样的？暖气片上烘着的棉袜、电视里播着的新闻联播、冰箱里的冻饺子……这些细节比任何历史叙述都更真实。
turns.content_en: Han Xue mentions "time capsule"—this makes me think of 1999's material culture: VCDs, pagers, "big brother" phones, 586 computers... These things were cutting-edge then, now nostalgic symbols. The artist uses archival materials and personal objects to reconstruct that year, actually reconstructing a sensory ecosystem. What was a 1999 Northeast household like? Socks drying on radiators, news broadcasting on TV, frozen dumplings in the fridge... These details are more real than any historical narrative.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 1999年对东北来说是一个关键节点。亚洲金融危机刚过，国企改革进入深水区，大批工人下岗。「下岗」这个词就是在90年代后期进入我们的日常语汇的。同时，这也是中国加入WTO前夕，全球化加速的前奏。艺术家的家庭档案，不只是私人记忆，也是这个历史转折期的微观缩影。一个家庭在1999年的决定——是留下还是离开，是坚守还是转型——往往决定了他们在21世纪的命运。
turns.content_en: 1999 was a crucial node for the Northeast. The Asian financial crisis had just passed, state enterprise reform entered deep water, massive layoffs occurred. "Xiagang" (laid off) entered our daily vocabulary in the late '90s. Meanwhile, this was the eve of China joining WTO, the prelude to accelerating globalization. The artist's family archive is not just private memory, but a micro-snapshot of this historical turning point. A family's decisions in 1999—to stay or leave, to persist or transform—often determined their fate in the 21st century.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 张伟教授提到「决定」，我想起我家也是在那几年做出重大决定的。爸爸的单位效益不好，妈妈在街道工厂上班，他们反复讨论要不要「下海」、要不要「南下」。那些大人深夜的对话，我隐约能听到——虽然听不懂具体内容，但能感受到那种焦虑。1999年的孩子，就是在这种焦虑的背景音里长大的。我们这代人骨子里的不安全感，或许就是那时候埋下的。
turns.content_en: Professor Zhang mentions "decisions"—I recall my family also made major decisions in those years. Dad's work unit had poor performance, Mom worked at a neighborhood factory; they repeatedly discussed whether to "dive into the sea" (start business), whether to "go south." Those late-night adult conversations I could vaguely hear—though I didn't understand specifics, I could feel that anxiety. Children of 1999 grew up against this background noise of anxiety. Our generation's deep-seated insecurity was perhaps planted then.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 韩雪说「背景音」，让我想到1999年的声音档案：邓丽君的磁带、央视的广告、楼道里的吵架声……这些声音构成了那个时代的听觉景观。我很好奇艺术家有没有在作品中加入这些声音元素。照片是静默的，但记忆是有声音的。当我们看一张1999年的家庭照，耳边应该响起什么？或许是春节联欢晚会的主持词，或许是小虎队的歌声，或许只是窗外汽车的喇叭声。这些声音和图像一样重要。
turns.content_en: Han Xue mentions "background noise"—this makes me think of 1999's sound archives: Teresa Teng cassettes, CCTV commercials, arguments in the corridor... These sounds formed that era's auditory landscape. I wonder if the artist included these sound elements. Photos are silent, but memory has sound. When we look at a 1999 family photo, what should we hear? Perhaps the Spring Festival Gala host's words, perhaps Little Tigers' songs, perhaps just car horns outside the window. These sounds are as important as images.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 李梅提到声音，我想补充一个观点：1999年也是中国互联网元年——门户网站兴起，网吧开始出现。这意味着一种新的记忆媒介正在诞生。从此以后，我们的记忆不只存储在相册和日记里，也存储在数据库和服务器上。这件作品使用的是「旧媒介」——照片、文件、物件，这本身就是一种选择：选择用手可以触摸的方式保存那个还没有被数字化的世界。1999年是分水岭，之后的一切都不一样了。这件作品站在那个分水岭上，向两边张望。
turns.content_en: Li Mei mentions sound; I'll add a viewpoint: 1999 was also Year One of China's internet—portal sites rose, internet cafes began appearing. This meant a new memory medium was being born. From then on, our memories were stored not just in albums and diaries, but in databases and servers. This work uses "old media"—photos, documents, objects—which itself is a choice: choosing to preserve that not-yet-digitized world in a way hands can touch. 1999 was a watershed; everything after was different. This work stands at that watershed, gazing both ways.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 作为一位日本艺术家，Yusuke Kuriki对物质肌理的关注让我印象深刻。日本美学中有一个概念叫「物派」，强调物质本身的存在感，而非人为的加工。这件作品延续了这种精神：不是把材料变成别的东西，而是让材料说话。东北亚的物质文化有什么共同点？或许就是那种「直接」——木头就是木头，铁就是铁，雪就是雪。这种直接性跨越国界，在整个区域都能找到共鸣。
turns.content_en: As a Japanese artist, Yusuke Kuriki's attention to material texture impresses me. Japanese aesthetics has a concept called "Mono-ha" (School of Things), emphasizing material's own presence rather than artificial processing. This work continues that spirit: not transforming material into something else, but letting material speak. What do Northeast Asian material cultures share? Perhaps that "directness"—wood is wood, iron is iron, snow is snow. This directness crosses borders, finding resonance throughout the region.

turns.speaker: okakura_tenshin
turns.content: 李梅言及「物派」，余以为此乃东方美学之精髓。西方艺术常以人为中心，人驾驭材料、塑造形式；东方艺术则尊重材料之本性，顺应而非强制。茶道中，我们欣赏茶碗之不完美——那些偶然的裂纹、不规则的釉色——正因其「自然」而美。此艺术家或许也在追求这种美：不是创造，而是发现；不是表达，而是聆听。物质会说话，只要我们愿意听。
turns.content_en: Li Mei mentions "Mono-ha"—I believe this is Eastern aesthetics' essence. Western art often centers on humans, humans mastering materials, shaping forms; Eastern art respects material's own nature, following rather than forcing. In tea ceremony, we appreciate tea bowls' imperfection—those accidental cracks, irregular glazes—beautiful precisely because "natural." This artist perhaps also pursues this beauty: not creating, but discovering; not expressing, but listening. Material speaks, if only we're willing to listen.

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 冈仓先生的「聆听」让我想到一个问题：谁有权「聆听」这片土地的物质？日本与东北的关系是复杂的——满洲国时期，日本人大量开发东北的资源：煤、铁、木材、粮食。这种开发不是「聆听」，而是「掠夺」。作为一位日本艺术家，Kuriki如何面对这段历史？我不是要道德审判，而是想说：任何关于东北亚物质文化的讨论，都无法回避殖民记忆。物质不只是感官的载体，也是历史的容器。
turns.content_en: Master Okakura's "listening" raises a question: who has the right to "listen" to this land's materials? Japan's relationship with the Northeast is complex—during Manchukuo, Japanese extensively extracted Northeast resources: coal, iron, timber, grain. This extraction wasn't "listening," but "plundering." As a Japanese artist, how does Kuriki face this history? I'm not making moral judgments, but saying: any discussion of Northeast Asian material culture cannot avoid colonial memory. Material is not just a carrier of senses, but a container of history.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 朴博士提出了一个尖锐但重要的问题。我想补充一点：物质记忆是多层叠加的。东北的一块铁，可能曾经是满铁的铁轨，后来被熔铸成建国后的机床，再后来变成下岗工人的收藏品。每一层使用都在物质上留下痕迹。艺术家关注物质肌理，其实也是在阅读这些层叠的历史。问题不在于「有权聆听」，而在于能否听出物质里沉默的历史——包括那些不光彩的部分。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park raises a sharp but important question. I'd add: material memory is multiply layered. A piece of Northeast iron might once have been South Manchuria Railway tracks, later recast into post-Liberation machine tools, later still becoming a laid-off worker's keepsake. Each layer of use leaves traces on the material. The artist focusing on material texture is actually reading these layered histories. The question isn't about "having the right to listen," but whether one can hear the silent history in material—including the disgraceful parts.

turns.speaker: okakura_tenshin
turns.content: 李梅言「层叠的历史」，余深有所感。余昔年反对日本全盘西化，然彼时日本亦在亚洲行殖民之事，此乃吾辈之痛。艺术不能逃避历史，但艺术或可开启对话。此作品若能让观者感受物质之美，同时思考物质之历史，便是成功。我以为，真正的「聆听」不是单向的接受，而是带着问题的对话。日本艺术家来东北创作，本身就是一种对话的姿态。重要的是这对话是否诚实、是否开放、是否愿意被质疑。
turns.content_en: Li Mei speaks of "layered history"—I feel this deeply. In my early years I opposed Japan's wholesale Westernization, yet at that time Japan was also colonizing Asia—this is our generation's pain. Art cannot escape history, but art can open dialogue. If this work lets viewers feel material's beauty while thinking about material's history, it succeeds. I believe true "listening" is not one-way reception, but dialogue with questions. A Japanese artist coming to the Northeast to create is itself a gesture of dialogue. What matters is whether this dialogue is honest, open, willing to be questioned.

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 冈仓先生说「愿意被质疑」，这是艺术家跨国创作时最需要的态度。我不是要求日本艺术家每件作品都道歉，而是希望看到对复杂性的承认。物质无罪，但物质承载的历史有是非。这件作品如果能够在感官愉悦之外，引发观者对物质背后历史的思考，那就超越了单纯的美学，进入了伦理的领域。东北亚的和解，需要的不只是外交辞令，还需要这样一件一件作品，一次一次对话，慢慢积累信任和理解。
turns.content_en: Master Okakura says "willing to be questioned"—this is the most needed attitude for artists creating across borders. I'm not demanding every Japanese artist's work apologize, but hoping to see acknowledgment of complexity. Material is innocent, but the history material carries has rights and wrongs. If this work, beyond sensory pleasure, can trigger viewers to think about the history behind material, it transcends pure aesthetics, entering the realm of ethics. Northeast Asia's reconciliation needs not just diplomatic rhetoric, but work after work, dialogue after dialogue, slowly accumulating trust and understanding.

notes: 日本艺术家，物质美学与殖民记忆反思

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: Kyra Zhang的作品探索「文化杂交」这个核心概念。在跨国流动的背景下，身份不再是单一的、固定的，而是多元的、流动的。一个有着中国名字「张」和西方名字「Kyra」的艺术家，本身就是这种杂交性的体现。作品追踪个人和集体的流离经验，探讨身份如何在不同文化的碰撞中被塑造、被质疑、被重新定义。这不是关于失去，而是关于转变。
turns.content_en: Kyra Zhang's work explores the core concept of "cultural hybridity." In the context of transnational movement, identity is no longer singular and fixed, but plural and fluid. An artist with a Chinese surname "Zhang" and Western first name "Kyra" embodies this hybridity. The work traces personal and collective experiences of displacement, exploring how identity is shaped, questioned, and redefined in the collision of different cultures. This is not about loss, but transformation.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 朴博士说「不是关于失去，而是关于转变」，但我想说，转变也是一种失去——失去那个曾经确定的自己。当你离开家乡，学会新的语言，适应新的习惯，你变成了另一个人。那个「旧的你」去哪了？这件作品让我思考：身份的杂交是否意味着某些东西必须被牺牲？Kyra和张，哪个更「真实」？还是说，真实的是那个在两者之间不断协商的过程本身？
turns.content_en: Dr. Park says "not about loss, but transformation," but I'd say transformation is also a kind of loss—losing that once-certain self. When you leave home, learn a new language, adapt to new customs, you become another person. Where did that "old you" go? This work makes me think: does identity's hybridity mean something must be sacrificed? Kyra and Zhang, which is more "real"? Or is what's real the process of constant negotiation between the two?

turns.speaker: dr_aris_thorne
turns.content: 韩雪提出的「协商」很关键。在数字时代，身份的协商变得更加复杂。我们在不同的平台上有不同的人设，用不同的语言和不同的群体交流。Kyra Zhang这一代人，是真正的「数字原住民」——他们的身份形成过程，从一开始就是多元的、碎片化的。这件作品如果能够反映这种数字化的身份协商，将会更具当代性。问题是：在虚拟和现实交织的世界里，什么是「真实」的身份？
turns.content_en: Han Xue's point about "negotiation" is crucial. In the digital age, identity negotiation becomes more complex. We have different personas on different platforms, communicating in different languages with different groups. Kyra Zhang's generation are true "digital natives"—their identity formation was plural and fragmented from the start. If this work can reflect this digitized identity negotiation, it would be more contemporary. The question is: in a world where virtual and real interweave, what is "real" identity?

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 索恩博士提到「数字原住民」，让我想到另一个维度：在线社群如何重塑离散身份。过去，离散者与家乡的联系依赖书信和偶尔的电话；现在，微信群、视频通话、社交媒体让「远方」变得触手可及。这改变了离散的本质——你可以身在异国，心在故乡；也可以反过来。Kyra Zhang的作品是否探讨了这种「虚拟归属」？如果是，它挑战了传统的「边界」概念。边界不再只是地理的，也是数字的、想象的。
turns.content_en: Dr. Thorne mentions "digital natives"—this makes me think of another dimension: how online communities reshape diaspora identity. In the past, diaspora's connection to homeland relied on letters and occasional calls; now, WeChat groups, video calls, social media make "far away" within reach. This changes diaspora's nature—you can be physically abroad, heart at home; or vice versa. Does Kyra Zhang's work explore this "virtual belonging"? If so, it challenges traditional concepts of "borders." Borders are no longer just geographic, but digital, imagined.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 朴博士说「心在故乡」，但有时候我不确定「故乡」在哪里了。我在东北出生，在北京上学，在上海工作，现在……到处都是家，到处都不是家。Kyra Zhang这个名字本身就透露出一种「之间性」——在Kyra和张之间，在这里和那里之间，在过去和未来之间。这件作品或许不是要给出答案，而是要承认这种「之间」的状态。悬而未决，不是问题，而是我们这代人的常态。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park says "heart at home," but sometimes I'm not sure where "home" is anymore. I was born in the Northeast, studied in Beijing, worked in Shanghai, now... everywhere is home, nowhere is home. The name Kyra Zhang itself reveals a kind of "in-betweenness"—between Kyra and Zhang, between here and there, between past and future. This work perhaps isn't trying to give answers, but to acknowledge this "in-between" state. Unresolved is not a problem, but our generation's normal state.

turns.speaker: dr_aris_thorne
turns.content: 韩雪说「悬而未决」，我觉得这正是这件作品的力量所在。传统的身份叙事强调「归属」——你要么属于这里，要么属于那里。但跨国流动的经验打破了这种二元对立。艺术可以做的，是创造一个空间，让「之间性」被看见、被尊重、被珍视。Kyra Zhang的作品或许不提供归宿，但它提供了陪伴——告诉那些同样迷路的人：你不是一个人在迷失。这是艺术的人道主义力量。
turns.content_en: Han Xue says "unresolved"—I think this is precisely this work's power. Traditional identity narratives emphasize "belonging"—you either belong here or belong there. But transnational movement experience breaks this binary opposition. What art can do is create a space where "in-betweenness" is seen, respected, treasured. Kyra Zhang's work may not provide a home, but it provides companionship—telling those equally lost: you're not alone in being lost. This is art's humanitarian power.

notes: 跨文化身份与数字时代视角

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: Yizheng Liu的作品聚焦「文化流离」。流离不只是地理上的移动，更是心理和文化上的错位。当你置身异国，你突然意识到那些曾经「自然」的东西——说话的方式、吃饭的习惯、过节的仪式——都变成了需要解释、需要调整、需要协商的「文化」。这种意识本身就是一种创伤，也是一种启蒙。艺术家用个人叙事和历史研究，试图理解这种流离的结构和机制。
turns.content_en: Yizheng Liu's work focuses on "cultural displacement." Displacement is not just geographic movement, but psychological and cultural dislocation. When you find yourself in a foreign country, you suddenly realize those once "natural" things—ways of speaking, eating habits, holiday rituals—all become "culture" that needs explanation, adjustment, negotiation. This awareness itself is both a wound and an enlightenment. The artist uses personal narrative and historical research, trying to understand displacement's structure and mechanisms.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 朴博士说「需要解释的文化」，这让我想起在异国过春节的经历。要向外国朋友解释为什么要包饺子、为什么要放鞭炮、为什么要给红包……每一次解释都是一次小小的自我疏离。你突然从「内部人」变成了「解说员」，用外部视角看自己的文化。这件作品探讨的或许就是这种「双重视角」——既是参与者，又是观察者；既是东北人，又是异乡客。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park says "culture needing explanation"—this reminds me of celebrating Spring Festival abroad. Having to explain to foreign friends why we make dumplings, why we set off firecrackers, why we give red packets... Each explanation is a small self-alienation. You suddenly shift from "insider" to "explainer," viewing your own culture from outside. What this work explores is perhaps this "double vision"—being both participant and observer; both Northeasterner and stranger.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 二位从个人经验切入，我想补充一个历史视角。东北人的流离有其结构性原因：计划经济时期，东北是重工业基地，人口流入；改革开放后，沿海成为发展重心，东北人口大量流出。「东北人在全国」成为一个社会现象——从海南的旅游从业者到深圳的创业者。Yizheng Liu如果能将个人的流离经验与这个宏观的人口流动趋势对照，作品将获得更深的历史纵深。
turns.content_en: You both approach from personal experience; I'll add a historical perspective. Northeasterners' displacement has structural causes: during the planned economy, the Northeast was a heavy industry base with population influx; after Reform and Opening, coastal areas became the development focus, Northeast population massively flowed out. "Northeasterners across the country" became a social phenomenon—from Hainan tourism workers to Shenzhen entrepreneurs. If Yizheng Liu can juxtapose personal displacement experience with this macro population movement trend, the work will gain deeper historical depth.

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 张伟教授提到「人口流动趋势」，让我想到另一个问题：流动不只是东北向外，也有外向东北。历史上，朝鲜人、俄罗斯人、日本人都曾流入东北，形成多元的文化景观。今天的东北亚流动更加复杂：韩国留学生在中国，中国劳工在日本，朝鲜难民穿越边境……Yizheng Liu的作品是否关注到这种多向度的流动？「流离」不是单向的损失，而是双向的交换，尽管这交换常常是不平等的。
turns.content_en: Professor Zhang mentions "population movement trends"—this makes me think of another question: movement is not just outward from Northeast, but also inward. Historically, Koreans, Russians, Japanese all flowed into the Northeast, forming a diverse cultural landscape. Today's Northeast Asian movement is more complex: Korean students in China, Chinese workers in Japan, North Korean refugees crossing borders... Does Yizheng Liu's work attend to this multi-directional movement? "Displacement" is not one-way loss, but two-way exchange, though this exchange is often unequal.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 朴博士说「不平等的交换」，这让我想到语言。离开东北的人，常常要学会「藏」起自己的口音——那种独特的东北腔调，在某些场合会成为被取笑的对象。这是一种「语言的流离」：你的母语变成了一种需要管理的资产，在某些场合展示，在另一些场合隐藏。Yizheng Liu的作品如果能够捕捉这种语言的协商，将会触及流离经验最微妙的部分。口音是身份的痕迹，也是流离的伤疤。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park mentions "unequal exchange"—this makes me think of language. Those who left the Northeast often had to learn to "hide" their accent—that distinctive Northeast tone that in some contexts becomes an object of mockery. This is a "linguistic displacement": your mother tongue becomes an asset requiring management, displayed in some contexts, hidden in others. If Yizheng Liu's work can capture this linguistic negotiation, it would touch the most subtle part of displacement experience. Accent is identity's trace, also displacement's scar.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 韩雪说「口音是流离的伤疤」，这个比喻很准确。东北方言在当代流行文化中有一种尴尬的位置：一方面是喜剧资源（二人转、小品），另一方面是身份焦虑。东北人在「自嘲」和「被嘲」之间寻找平衡。这件作品如果能够反映这种复杂的文化政治，将会超越简单的乡愁叙事。流离不只是离开家乡，也是失去在公共空间中舒适说话的权利。艺术可以成为重新获得这种权利的途径。
turns.content_en: Han Xue says "accent is displacement's scar"—this metaphor is accurate. Northeast dialect holds an awkward position in contemporary popular culture: on one hand a comedy resource (er'ren zhuan, sketches), on the other identity anxiety. Northeasterners seek balance between "self-mockery" and "being mocked." If this work can reflect this complex cultural politics, it will transcend simple nostalgia narrative. Displacement is not just leaving home, but losing the right to speak comfortably in public space. Art can become a way to regain that right.

notes: 文化流离与语言政治视角

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 藤本陆人的作品让我想到一个概念：触觉的跨文化性。当我们触摸一块木头、一片冰、一张纸的时候，这种感觉是超越语言和国界的。日本人和中国人摸到同一种材料，会有相似的触感经验。这件作品探索的正是这种「普遍触觉」——通过物质的肌理，建立跨文化的共情。温度、纹理、重量——这些是身体的共同语言。
turns.content_en: Rikuto Fujimoto's work makes me think of a concept: the cross-cultural nature of touch. When we touch a piece of wood, a sheet of ice, a piece of paper, this sensation transcends language and borders. Japanese and Chinese touching the same material have similar tactile experiences. This work explores precisely this "universal touch"—building cross-cultural empathy through material texture. Temperature, texture, weight—these are the body's common language.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 李梅说「身体的共同语言」，让我想起东北的冬天。零下三十度的寒冷是无法翻译的——你要么经历过，要么没有。日本北海道也有这样的冬天，俄罗斯西伯利亚也有。这种极端的身体经验，成为东北亚居民的共享记忆。艺术家如果能够唤起这种感觉，哪怕只是一瞬间的寒意，就已经完成了一次跨境的交流。感官是最原始的，也是最真实的连接方式。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "body's common language"—this reminds me of Northeast winters. Thirty-below-zero cold is untranslatable—you either experienced it or you didn't. Japan's Hokkaido has such winters too, as does Russia's Siberia. This extreme bodily experience becomes shared memory for Northeast Asian inhabitants. If the artist can evoke this feeling, even just a momentary chill, they've already achieved a cross-border exchange. The senses are most primal, also the most authentic form of connection.

turns.speaker: okakura_tenshin
turns.content: 韩雪言「原始的连接」，余深以为然。东方艺术之精髓，不在视觉之夺目，而在触觉之细腻。茶碗之妙，在手握之间方能体会；书法之韵，在笔墨触纸方能感知。此艺术家重视触觉，正是承继东方传统。然今日之展览，观者往往只能「看」而不能「摸」——这是一个遗憾。我期望这件作品能找到方式，让观者不只用眼睛，更用手掌、用皮肤来感受。触觉不能被复制，必须亲身体验。
turns.content_en: Han Xue says "primal connection"—I deeply agree. Eastern art's essence lies not in visual spectacle, but in tactile delicacy. A tea bowl's wonder can only be appreciated when held in hand; calligraphy's rhyme can only be felt when brush touches paper. This artist's emphasis on touch precisely continues Eastern tradition. Yet in today's exhibitions, viewers often can only "see" not "touch"—this is a regret. I hope this work can find ways to let viewers sense not just with eyes, but with palms, with skin. Touch cannot be replicated; it must be experienced firsthand.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 冈仓先生提到「亲身体验」，这是感官艺术的核心挑战。传统展览以视觉为中心，触觉被边缘化。但越来越多的当代艺术家在打破这个限制：可触摸的雕塑、可行走的装置、可闻的气味作品……藤本如果能让观者真正触碰到作品中的材料——东北亚特有的木头、金属、冰块——那将是一次真正的感官穿越。触摸是最亲密的感官，也是最有记忆力的感官。
turns.content_en: Master Okakura mentions "firsthand experience"—this is the core challenge of sensory art. Traditional exhibitions center on vision; touch is marginalized. But more and more contemporary artists are breaking this limitation: touchable sculptures, walkable installations, smellable scent works... If Fujimoto can let viewers truly touch the materials in the work—wood, metal, ice unique to Northeast Asia—it would be a true sensory crossing. Touch is the most intimate sense, also the most memorable sense.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 李梅说「触摸是最有记忆力的感官」，这让我想起奶奶的手。她的手粗糙、温暖、有力，握住我的手的时候我能感觉到她一辈子的劳作。那种触感我永远不会忘记，即使她已经不在了。艺术能不能保存这种触感的记忆？藤本的作品或许不是在创造新的触觉，而是在唤醒旧的触觉——那些我们以为已经遗忘，但其实一直埋藏在皮肤记忆里的东西。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "touch is the most memorable sense"—this reminds me of Grandma's hands. Her hands were rough, warm, strong; when she held my hands I could feel her lifetime of labor. That touch I'll never forget, even though she's gone. Can art preserve this tactile memory? Fujimoto's work perhaps isn't creating new touch, but awakening old touch—those things we thought we'd forgotten, but were actually buried in skin memory all along.

turns.speaker: okakura_tenshin
turns.content: 韩雪所言「皮肤记忆」，甚是动人。余以为，最好的艺术不是展示，而是召唤——召唤观者自己的记忆、自己的经验、自己的情感。此艺术家来自日本，创作关于东北亚的作品，但他召唤的或许是每个人心中共有的触觉记忆：握住亲人的手、踩在雪地上、抚摸旧家具的纹理……这些记忆不分国界。艺术的力量在于：它让陌生人变成同路人，因为我们触碰过同样的世界。
turns.content_en: What Han Xue calls "skin memory" is deeply moving. I believe the best art is not display, but summoning—summoning viewers' own memories, own experiences, own emotions. This artist comes from Japan, creating work about Northeast Asia, but what he summons may be tactile memories common to everyone's heart: holding a loved one's hand, stepping on snow, touching the grain of old furniture... These memories know no borders. Art's power lies in this: it makes strangers into fellow travelers, because we've touched the same world.

notes: 日本艺术家，触觉记忆视角

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: Fanglin Luo的作品关注「非视觉感官」——嗅觉、味觉、触觉、听觉。这些感官在艺术史上长期被边缘化，因为它们难以被记录、传播、保存。但对于记忆来说，这些感官才是最有力的触发器。普鲁斯特的玛德琳蛋糕就是一个经典例子：一种味道打开了整个童年的记忆之门。这件作品或许在探索：如何用艺术的方式保存那些无法被拍摄的感官体验？
turns.content_en: Fanglin Luo's work focuses on "non-visual senses"—smell, taste, touch, hearing. These senses have long been marginalized in art history because they're difficult to record, transmit, preserve. But for memory, these senses are the most powerful triggers. Proust's madeleine is a classic example: one taste opened the entire door to childhood memory. This work perhaps explores: how can art preserve sensory experiences that cannot be photographed?

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 李梅说「无法被拍摄的感官」，让我想起东北的气味。白菜在院子里发酵的酸味，煤炉子燃烧的烟味，冻雪融化的清新味……这些气味我闭上眼睛就能闻到，但我没有办法给别人展示。这件作品如果能够激活这种「气味记忆」，将是一次真正的感官革命。遗憾的是，我们没有图片来参考这件作品，只能靠文字描述来想象。但也许这正是艺术家想要的：让你用自己的感官去填充。
turns.content_en: Li Mei mentions "senses that cannot be photographed"—this reminds me of the Northeast's smells. The sour smell of cabbage fermenting in the yard, the smoke smell of burning coal stoves, the fresh smell of frozen snow melting... I can smell these with eyes closed, but I cannot show them to others. If this work can activate this "smell memory," it would be a true sensory revolution. Unfortunately, we have no pictures to reference this work, we can only imagine through text description. But perhaps this is what the artist wants: to have you fill in with your own senses.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 韩雪提到「用自己的感官去填充」，这让我想到口述传统。我们格里奥从不写下故事，而是口口相传。每一次讲述都是不同的，因为讲述者会加入自己的声调、停顿、表情。这种「不完整」反而让故事更有生命力。Fanglin Luo的作品或许也在追求这种效果：不给你完整的感官体验，而是给你线索，让你用自己的记忆去完成。这样一来，每个观者看到的都是不同的作品——因为每个人的感官记忆都是独特的。
turns.content_en: Han Xue mentions "fill in with your own senses"—this reminds me of oral tradition. We griots never write down stories, but pass them mouth to mouth. Each telling is different, because the teller adds their own tone, pauses, expressions. This "incompleteness" actually gives stories more life. Fanglin Luo's work perhaps also pursues this effect: not giving you complete sensory experience, but giving you clues, letting you complete it with your own memory. This way, each viewer sees a different work—because everyone's sensory memory is unique.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 佐拉妈妈说「每个人的感官记忆都是独特的」，这提出了一个有趣的问题：如何创作关于感官的艺术，同时尊重观者的主体性？太具体会限制想象，太抽象又失去共鸣。Fanglin Luo需要找到一个平衡点：提供足够的感官线索来唤起共同的文化记忆（比如东北的冷、东北的食物），同时留出足够的空白让个人记忆填入。这是感官艺术最大的挑战，也是最大的魅力。
turns.content_en: Mama Zola says "everyone's sensory memory is unique"—this raises an interesting question: how to create art about the senses while respecting viewer subjectivity? Too specific limits imagination, too abstract loses resonance. Fanglin Luo needs to find a balance: providing enough sensory clues to evoke shared cultural memory (like the Northeast's cold, Northeast food), while leaving enough blank space for personal memory to fill in. This is sensory art's greatest challenge, and greatest charm.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 李梅说「共同的文化记忆」，我想到东北有一些几乎所有人都共享的感官体验：腊八粥的香、暖气片的热、雪地里嘎吱嘎吱的脚步声……这些是「感官的公约数」。即使我们没有见过这件作品，仅凭「嗅觉、味觉、触觉、听觉」这几个词，我脑海里就已经浮现出无数画面——或者说，无数感觉。这就是感官记忆的力量：它不需要看见，只需要暗示，就能触发整个记忆网络。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "shared cultural memory"—I think the Northeast has some sensory experiences almost everyone shares: the fragrance of Laba porridge, the heat of radiators, the crunch-crunch of footsteps in snow... These are "sensory common denominators." Even without seeing this work, just the words "smell, taste, touch, hearing" already conjure countless images in my mind—or rather, countless sensations. This is sensory memory's power: it doesn't need seeing, just suggestion, to trigger the entire memory network.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 韩雪说「不需要看见，只需要暗示」，这让我想到艺术的本质。最好的艺术不是给你答案，而是给你问题；不是展示你已知的，而是唤起你忘记的。Fanglin Luo的作品，即使我们没有图片，但通过这场对话，它已经在我们心中激活了某些东西。这就是好艺术的标志：它超越了物理的在场，在观者的记忆中生根发芽。感官会衰退，但感官的记忆永远存在。这件作品提醒我们：去闻、去尝、去触摸、去倾听——因为这些才是真正的档案。
turns.content_en: Han Xue says "doesn't need seeing, just suggestion"—this makes me think of art's essence. The best art doesn't give you answers, but questions; doesn't show what you know, but evokes what you've forgotten. Fanglin Luo's work, even without pictures, through this dialogue has already activated something in our hearts. This is the mark of good art: it transcends physical presence, taking root in viewers' memories. Senses may decline, but sensory memory exists forever. This work reminds us: smell, taste, touch, listen—because these are the true archives.

notes: 无图片作品，关注非视觉感官

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: Yiwen Liang的作品关注「日常生活的物质性」。这让我想起那些我们每天接触却很少注意的东西：门把手的金属凉意、筷子的木头纹理、棉被的蓬松触感……这些物质构成了我们生活的「肌理」。离开一个地方，最先忘记的是风景，最后忘记的是触感——那些与身体最亲近的物质记忆。这件作品或许在提醒我们：慢下来，感受那些正在触碰你的东西。
turns.content_en: Yiwen Liang's work focuses on "the materiality of everyday life." This reminds me of things we touch daily yet rarely notice: door handles' metal coolness, chopsticks' wood grain, quilts' fluffy touch... These materials constitute our life's "texture." When leaving a place, the first thing forgotten is scenery, the last thing forgotten is touch—those material memories closest to the body. This work perhaps reminds us: slow down, feel what's touching you.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 李梅说「与身体最亲近的物质记忆」，让我想到东北的炕。炕是东北人的床，但不只是床——它是冬天最温暖的地方，是全家人围坐的中心，是孩子打滚玩耍的乐园。炕的热是一种特殊的热：从下面渗上来，穿过被褥，进入骨头。这种热我在任何其他地方都没有再感受过。Yiwen Liang如果能够唤起这种「炕的记忆」，将会触动每一个东北人的心。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "material memories closest to the body"—this makes me think of the Northeast's kang (heated bed platform). The kang is Northeasterners' bed, but not just a bed—it's the warmest place in winter, the center where the whole family gathers, the playground where children roll around. The kang's heat is a special kind of heat: seeping up from below, through bedding, into bones. This heat I've never felt anywhere else. If Yiwen Liang can evoke this "kang memory," it will touch every Northeasterner's heart.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 韩雪提到炕，这是一个很好的物质文化案例。炕的出现与东北的气候和燃料供应有关：冬天漫长寒冷，烧炕可以一举两得——取暖和做饭。但随着城市化和集中供暖的普及，炕正在消失。年轻一代东北人，很多已经没有睡过炕了。这件作品如果关注这些「消失中的日常」，将具有抢救性的价值。每一种物质形式的消失，都是一种生活方式的终结。
turns.content_en: Han Xue mentions kang—this is an excellent material culture case. The kang's appearance relates to the Northeast's climate and fuel supply: winters are long and cold, heating the kang serves two purposes—warming and cooking. But with urbanization and centralized heating, kangs are disappearing. Many young Northeasterners have never slept on a kang. If this work focuses on these "disappearing dailiness," it would have salvage value. Each material form's disappearance is the end of a way of life.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 张伟教授说「消失中的日常」，让我想到物质的时间性。物质不是静止的，它们在使用中磨损、变形、消失。一双鞋穿久了会变形成脚的形状，一把椅子坐久了会留下身体的印痕。这些「使用的痕迹」是时间的物质化表达。Yiwen Liang的作品如果能够捕捉这些痕迹，就是在保存时间本身。我们无法阻止物质的消失，但我们可以记住它们曾经如何被使用、如何被爱过。
turns.content_en: Professor Zhang mentions "disappearing dailiness"—this makes me think of material's temporality. Materials aren't static; they wear, deform, disappear through use. Shoes worn long enough take the shape of feet; chairs sat in long enough leave body's imprint. These "traces of use" are time's materialized expression. If Yiwen Liang's work can capture these traces, it's preserving time itself. We can't stop materials from disappearing, but we can remember how they were used, how they were loved.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 李梅说「如何被爱过」，这个表达很打动我。物质不只是工具，也是情感的载体。奶奶的针线盒、爸爸的工具箱、妈妈的厨房用具——这些东西被使用过几十年，上面沾满了主人的汗水和体温。当这些人不在了，这些物质就成了他们的遗物，成了唯一可以触摸的记忆。Yiwen Liang的作品让我意识到：我们应该更珍惜那些日常的物质，因为它们就是我们生活的证据。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "how they were loved"—this expression moves me. Material isn't just tools, but carriers of emotion. Grandma's sewing box, Dad's toolbox, Mom's kitchen utensils—these things were used for decades, covered with their owners' sweat and body heat. When these people are gone, these materials become their relics, the only touchable memories. Yiwen Liang's work makes me realize: we should treasure more those everyday materials, because they are the evidence of our lives.

turns.speaker: northeast_historian
turns.content: 韩雪说「生活的证据」，这让我想到物质文化研究的一个核心问题：如何从物质中读出历史？一件物品的材料、工艺、磨损程度、修补痕迹——这些都是信息。一个东北家庭的日常物质，可以告诉我们他们的经济状况、生活习惯、审美偏好。Yiwen Liang的作品如果能够「阅读」这些物质，将会为我们提供一种另类的历史叙述：不是从上而下的政策史，而是从下而上的日常史。这是最真实、最亲切的历史。
turns.content_en: Han Xue says "evidence of life"—this makes me think of a core question in material culture studies: how to read history from material? An item's material, craft, degree of wear, repair traces—these are all information. A Northeast family's everyday materials can tell us their economic situation, living habits, aesthetic preferences. If Yiwen Liang's work can "read" these materials, it would provide us an alternative historical narrative: not top-down policy history, but bottom-up everyday history. This is the most real, most intimate history.

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 作为一位韩国学者，我对这件作品特别关注。Jungyun Lee的视频/表演作品探讨的是「历史的幽灵」——那些未被安葬的记忆、未被解决的创伤。在朝鲜半岛的语境里，这种「幽灵」有着具体的面目：分裂家庭的思念、战争遗骸的寻找、慰安妇的证言……这些历史创伤像幽灵一样游荡，无法安息。艺术家用表演来召唤这些幽灵，让他们在当代空间里获得短暂的可见性。
turns.content_en: As a Korean scholar, I pay special attention to this work. Jungyun Lee's video/performance work explores "ghosts of history"—those unburied memories, unresolved traumas. In the Korean Peninsula's context, these "ghosts" have concrete faces: divided families' longing, searching for war remains, comfort women's testimonies... These historical traumas wander like ghosts, unable to rest. The artist uses performance to summon these ghosts, giving them brief visibility in contemporary space.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 朴博士说「召唤幽灵」，这让我想到东北的民间信仰。在东北农村，有一种叫「跳大神」的仪式，萨满巫师通过舞蹈和歌唱召唤祖先的灵魂。这不是迷信，而是一种处理创伤的方式：让过去的亡灵说话，让活着的人聆听。韩国的萨满传统和东北有相似之处，都相信死者与生者之间的界限是可以穿越的。艺术家或许就是当代的萨满，用表演代替仪式，用视频代替篝火。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park mentions "summoning ghosts"—this reminds me of Northeast folk beliefs. In rural Northeast, there's a ritual called "jumping the great spirit" where shamans summon ancestral spirits through dance and song. This isn't superstition, but a way of processing trauma: letting past souls speak, letting the living listen. Korean shamanic tradition shares similarities with the Northeast's, both believing the boundary between dead and living can be crossed. The artist is perhaps a contemporary shaman, using performance instead of ritual, video instead of bonfire.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 韩雪说的萨满传统，和我们格里奥的工作很像。格里奥也是与祖先对话的人——我们唱颂词、讲故事、保存家族的记忆。当一个人死去，如果没有人讲述他的故事，他的灵魂就真的消失了。艺术家在做的也是这种工作：为那些被历史遗忘的人发声，让他们的故事被听见。表演艺术的力量在于「在场」——观众和表演者在同一个空间里，共同见证记忆的复活。这种力量是录像无法完全替代的。
turns.content_en: The shamanic tradition Han Xue mentions is similar to griot work. Griots also dialogue with ancestors—we sing praise songs, tell stories, preserve family memories. When a person dies, if no one tells their story, their soul truly disappears. The artist is doing this kind of work: giving voice to those forgotten by history, letting their stories be heard. Performance art's power lies in "presence"—audience and performer in the same space, together witnessing memory's resurrection. This power cannot be fully replaced by video.

turns.speaker: border_theorist
turns.content: 佐拉妈妈提到「在场」，这让我思考视频媒介的意义。表演是临时的、不可重复的，但视频可以保存、传播、反复观看。这是一个权衡：为了让更多人看到，我们牺牲了「在场」的独特性。艺术家选择视频，可能是为了跨越边界——让首尔的故事被北京的观众看到，让哈尔滨的观众理解釜山的创伤。视频成为一种桥梁，连接不同的历史记忆。幽灵不再受地理限制，可以在全球游荡。
turns.content_en: Mama Zola mentions "presence"—this makes me think about video medium's meaning. Performance is temporary, unrepeatable; but video can be preserved, transmitted, watched repeatedly. This is a tradeoff: to be seen by more people, we sacrifice "presence's" uniqueness. The artist choosing video may be to cross borders—letting Seoul's stories be seen by Beijing's audience, letting Harbin's audience understand Busan's trauma. Video becomes a bridge, connecting different historical memories. Ghosts no longer bound by geography, can wander globally.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 朴博士说「幽灵游荡」，我想到东北亚的历史是如何纠缠在一起的。日本殖民朝鲜，又占领满洲；朝鲜战争爆发，中国志愿军跨过鸭绿江；后来是冷战分裂，南北对峙……这些历史事件在不同国家产生了不同的幽灵，但这些幽灵是相互关联的。一个韩国艺术家创作关于历史幽灵的作品，放在东北展览里展出，本身就是一种跨境对话。幽灵们在对话，我们活着的人也应该对话。
turns.content_en: Dr. Park mentions "ghosts wandering"—I think of how Northeast Asian history is intertwined. Japan colonized Korea, then occupied Manchuria; the Korean War broke out, Chinese volunteers crossed the Yalu; then Cold War division, North-South confrontation... These historical events produced different ghosts in different countries, but these ghosts are interconnected. A Korean artist creating work about historical ghosts, exhibited in Northeast China, is itself a cross-border dialogue. Ghosts are in dialogue; we the living should also dialogue.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 韩雪说「活着的人也应该对话」，这是这件作品最重要的启示。幽灵之所以游荡，是因为有未竟之事——未被承认的罪行、未被抚慰的伤痛、未被原谅的仇恨。只有当活着的人愿意面对这些，幽灵才能安息。艺术不能替代政治和解，但它可以为和解创造条件：让人们看见那些被遮蔽的历史，听见那些被沉默的声音。这件作品是一个邀请——邀请观众成为见证者，邀请不同国家的人一起面对那些共同的幽灵。这是艺术可以做到的事。
turns.content_en: Han Xue says "we the living should also dialogue"—this is this work's most important insight. Ghosts wander because there's unfinished business—unacknowledged crimes, uncomforted pain, unforgiven hatred. Only when the living are willing to face these can ghosts rest. Art cannot replace political reconciliation, but it can create conditions for it: letting people see concealed history, hear silenced voices. This work is an invitation—inviting viewers to become witnesses, inviting people from different countries to together face those shared ghosts. This is what art can do.

notes: 韩国艺术家，跨国幽灵叙事视角

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: Shuyi Alice Wang——又是一个东西方名字并置的艺术家。「淑怡」是传统中国女性名字，「Alice」则带有西方童话的气息。这种命名本身就是一个小型的文化档案：父母的期望、时代的影响、个人的选择，都凝缩在名字里。艺术家用档案和口述史来追溯家庭记忆，或许也是在追问：我是谁？我从哪里来？这些问题，每一个离散者都会问，每一个寻根者都在回答。
turns.content_en: Shuyi Alice Wang—another artist with both Eastern and Western names juxtaposed. "Shuyi" is a traditional Chinese woman's name, "Alice" carries Western fairy tale essence. This naming itself is a small cultural archive: parents' expectations, era's influence, personal choice, all condensed in a name. The artist uses archives and oral history to trace family memory, perhaps also asking: Who am I? Where do I come from? These questions every diaspora person asks, every roots-seeker answers.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 韩雪提到「口述史」，这让我特别感兴趣。口述史是一种特殊的感官档案：它依赖声音、语调、停顿、叹息……这些是文字无法完全捕捉的。当奶奶讲述她年轻时的故事，她的声音会颤抖、会升高、会变得遥远——这些都是叙述的一部分。Shuyi Alice Wang如果在作品中保留了这些声音的「原始状态」，将会比任何文字记录都更动人。声音是记忆的另一种物质形式。
turns.content_en: Han Xue mentions "oral history"—this particularly interests me. Oral history is a special sensory archive: it relies on sound, tone, pauses, sighs... things text cannot fully capture. When Grandma tells stories of her youth, her voice trembles, rises, becomes distant—these are all part of the narration. If Shuyi Alice Wang preserves these sounds' "raw state" in the work, it would be more moving than any written record. Sound is another material form of memory.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 李梅说「声音是记忆的物质形式」，这正是格里奥的信念。在我们的传统里，故事必须用声音传递，因为只有声音才能携带灵魂。书写是死的，声音是活的——它会随着讲述者的情绪变化，随着听众的反应变化。Shuyi Alice Wang收集家庭的口述史，就像我收集村庄的故事一样。我们都是记忆的守护者，用声音对抗遗忘。每一次讲述，都是一次小小的复活。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "sound is memory's material form"—this is precisely the griot's belief. In our tradition, stories must be transmitted through voice, because only voice can carry soul. Writing is dead, voice is alive—it changes with the teller's emotion, with the listener's response. Shuyi Alice Wang collecting family oral histories is like me collecting village stories. We're both guardians of memory, using voice to resist forgetting. Each telling is a small resurrection.

turns.speaker: diaspora_poet
turns.content: 佐拉妈妈说「复活」，这个词让我想到家庭故事的代际传递。我奶奶讲她的故事，我妈妈听着长大；我妈妈讲她的故事，我听着长大；等我有了孩子，我会讲我的故事。但问题是：每一次传递都会有损失和添加，最终哪些会留下来？Shuyi Alice Wang的作品或许在做一种「抢救」：把那些还没来得及传递的故事记录下来，防止它们随着老一辈的离去而永远消失。这是一种爱，也是一种责任。
turns.content_en: Mama Zola says "resurrection"—this word makes me think of family stories' intergenerational transmission. My grandmother told her story, my mother grew up listening; my mother told her story, I grew up listening; when I have children, I'll tell my story. But the question is: each transmission has loss and addition; ultimately what remains? Shuyi Alice Wang's work is perhaps a kind of "rescue": recording stories not yet transmitted, preventing them from disappearing forever with elders' passing. This is a kind of love, also a responsibility.

turns.speaker: sensory_archivist
turns.content: 韩雪说「抢救」，让我想到这件作品没有图片的事实。或许对于口述史来说，图片反而是次要的——重要的是声音，是语言，是讲述者的气息。我们这场对话也是一种口述：我们在用语言描绘一件我们没有看见的作品，创造一种基于文字的「想象展览」。这正好呼应了口述史的本质：它不依赖视觉证据，而依赖语言的力量。Shuyi Alice Wang的作品，即使没有图片，也已经在我们的对话中「展出」了。
turns.content_en: Han Xue mentions "rescue"—this makes me think of this work having no pictures. Perhaps for oral history, pictures are secondary—what matters is sound, language, the teller's breath. Our dialogue is also a kind of oral narration: we're using language to describe a work we haven't seen, creating an "imagined exhibition" based on text. This echoes oral history's essence: it doesn't rely on visual evidence, but on language's power. Shuyi Alice Wang's work, even without pictures, has already been "exhibited" in our dialogue.

turns.speaker: mama_zola
turns.content: 李梅说「想象展览」，这是个美丽的说法。在我们格里奥的世界里，每一个听众脑海中的画面都是不同的——因为我们只提供声音，画面由听众自己绘制。Shuyi Alice Wang的家庭口述史也是如此：她提供声音和故事，每个观众在自己的脑海中重建那个家庭、那段历史、那些人物。这是一种参与式的艺术：观众不是被动的接受者，而是主动的共创者。每一个家庭故事都是独特的，但每一个听故事的人都能从中看到自己的家庭。这就是口述的魔力。
turns.content_en: Li Mei says "imagined exhibition"—that's a beautiful phrase. In our griot world, each listener's mental image is different—because we only provide sound, the picture is drawn by listeners themselves. Shuyi Alice Wang's family oral history is the same: she provides voice and story, each viewer rebuilds that family, that history, those people in their own mind. This is participatory art: viewers are not passive receivers, but active co-creators. Every family story is unique, but every story-listener can see their own family in it. This is the magic of oral transmission.
